comments.author: Angel Rodriguez

comments.text:
+Mark Metzger Have you ever seen a brain? Do you know of the corpus 
callosum? Also no, it just so happens that the neuronal activity 
responsible for 'problem solving', 'counting' and other things that you 
need to do math, is on that side of the brain. Having dyslexia doesn't mean 
you won't be able to do math(that's dyscalculia). But since you have 
dyslexia(a brain deficiency) you are also likely to have other accompanying 
deficiencies. It's just luck I guess. But the separation of the two 
hemispheres is very real(unless you want to talk about neuroplasticity and 
how one side of the brain can take tasks that the other does).
comments.author: Alex Hatz (Razgrits)

comments.text:
Dyslexia usually comes hand in hand with either dysculcalia, dysgraphia or

disabilities, so long as you overcome dyslexia you should be SHOULD BE

comments.text:

comments.author: Kathy Sothman

comments.text:
+Ray j
Actually, Dyslexia is NOT reading...it is LANGUAGE difficulty that affects 
reading-or many other things. MANY MANY dyslexics can read b/c they have 
memorized word shapes and compensated in other ways. They do, however, 
process slower b/c of this as they read. Dys= Difficulty with. Lexia= 
Language.- in Greek. Dyslexia involves not just reading or spelling, but 
involves AUDITORY processing of language. They hear whole words not parts, 
and have much difficulty w/ the normal phonics/sounding out because they 
don't hear letter to letter. It may also involve rhyming, directionality 
(up down & left right--thus backwards letters, but also directionality in 
other parts of life.) It can affect memory. It is an inherited trait--50/50 
chance. It can be extremely MILD or very PROFOUND. They may have trouble w/ 
oral language as a child, memorizing arbitrary facts, sequencing, and more! 
Dysgraphia is not spelling. Dys=Difficulty with. Graphia=meaning writing. 
NOT spelling. Two completely different things. The dyslexic brain is 
actually different than that of someone w/out dyslexia. The right hemispere 
is normally 10% smaller than the left. Dyslexics have both sides the 
same--not because one side is smaller, but because the right is larger! 
Because of this, many are gifted in Art, Athletics, Music and much more!!!! 
There ARE programs that help with it!!!
comments.author: Kathy Sothman

comments.text: Dyslexic is reading not spelling, spelling is Dysgraphia.
comments.author: Ray j

comments.author: adelle Pulga

top_comment.text:
There is absolutely no evidence of this nonsense about people with dyslexia 
needing some special multi-sensory approaches to reading. Students with 
dyslexia need the same kind of quality reading instruction that students 
without dyslexia need. Those who claim otherwise are generally trying to 
sell something.﻿
top_comment.author: Samuel DeJulio

comments.text:
+Samuel DeJulio Your opinion is fair enough in my opinion. I would argue 
teachers specialising in teaching dyslexics will have developed experience 
of processes that work for many dyslexics and can probably help find 
 methods for each individual quicker than someone trying by themselves. 
Regarding your speculating point, trialling different methods I beleive has 
a plenty of merit for dyslexics, the benefits could be large for all anyone 
knows. I suspect many are low to zero cost (a book perhaps, a voice 
recorder etc. or just attempting to consciously think differently, 
remembering to use spell check!). Having said that I personally have 
shocking working memory relative to other aspects of IQ. Besides practice 
and the use of common memory techniques such as creating stories I have 
found precious little information on how to try and improve that aspect (I 
researched brain training games and there seems little evidence in the 
scientific community for their effectiveness). I will keep looking however! 
I mainly just have to try to override the symptoms with reliance on 
technology for organisation etc.
comments.author: Jonathan Roman

comments.text:
+Jonathan Roman The problem tends to be a matter of the claims outrunning 
the research. Until dyslexia can be clearly defined there really isn't any 
way to talk about what dyslexics need. Individuals identified with dyslexia 
can differ so greatly that the label itself can be unhelpful. Until we have 
research focused on specific categories within dyslexia along with evidence 
that there are interventions that are specific to these conditions we are 
simply speculating. I'm not opposed to the idea that the science is getting 
us closer-in fact some of it is really exciting. I'm simply against the 
idea that there are people claiming to have the answers when the research 
isn't there.
comments.author: Samuel DeJulio

comments.text:
+Samuel DeJulio They're getting pretty close to identifying the differences 
in brain functioning for dyslexics and non-dyslexics. This is fairly new 
research I believe. Up to now, as you say, diagnosis is from symptoms which 
may have led to some mis-diagnosis. Symptoms are also determined by many 
other factors in individuals lives (specific problems with dyslexia can be 
combatted with practise for example). That does not rule out the 
possibility there being a very large group of people with dyslexia (indeed 
the evidence is very strong there is), with the same brain types. I agree 
that individuals need to treated as individuals. But dyslexics brains do 
function very differently to the rest of the population (which common 
teaching practises cater for). It's not unreasonable to suggest there are 
probably methods that work better for the group of dyslexics on average. 
Indeed coloured overlays may not work at all for the rest of the population 
and so they may think they are stupid merely because they don't work for 
them. I myself have no experience with coloured overlays so I can't comment 
on that specific method however. Living in the UK I would look to the state 
to provide advice/help with dyslexia rather than trusting other products 
unless you researched purchases very thoroughly.
comments.author: Jonathan Roman

comments.text:
If coloured overlays work for some people then why not believe it helps? 
Just because you feel it's a myth others don't. Respect other peoples 
opinions.
comments.author: Nicole's Niche

comments.text: You're just an idiot.
comments.author: Scott Yates

comments.text:
I must've hit a nerve. You can believe in unicorns and colored overlays all 
you want.
comments.author: Samuel DeJulio

comments.text: You don't know anything about being Dyslexic so you need to stfu.
comments.author: Scott Yates

comments.text: Which part do you disagree with? Or are you just venting?
comments.author: Samuel DeJulio

comments.text: You're an ignoramus.
comments.author: Scott Yates

comments.text:
The colored overlays have the same benefit as a placebo (kind of like the 
magic feather in the movie Dumbo). The benefits of colored overlays are not 
supported by any research. While I wouldn’t have a problem with people 
using them in order to simply believe that they can read better with them 
(increased belief in one’s ability to read is a good thing), the colored 
overlays are marketed to people as a treatment for their dyslexia by snake 
oil salesmen. People who seek answers for their reading difficulties are 
often victims to this exploitation.
comments.author: Samuel DeJulio

comments.text:
When I say that there is no test for dyslexia I am referring to the fact 
that there is no way to medically diagnose it (you might think of it more 
like high-blood pressure that is found on a continuum rather than measles 
that can be present or absent). In fact, there is not even an agreed upon 
definition of dyslexia, and the criteria vary widely. When people attempt 
to diagnose dyslexia they are looking for indicators that suggest dyslexia 
(trouble decoding and spelling), none of which is a defining characteristic 
of the condition. In fact, a child could be considered dyslexic according 
to one test or diagnostician, but not by another. What is most troubling is 
how often the people who do the testing are the people selling the products 
or services to treat dyslexia…and they stand to benefit by giving people 
the dyslexic label. When you said that no two people with dyslexia are the 
same I totally agree. This is really the problem with most programs. 
Believing that reading difficulties can be addressed with a standardized 
method ignores the individual needs of each learner. There should be less 
focus on the term dyslexia and more focus on addressing the specific needs 
of the individual.
comments.author: Samuel DeJulio

comments.text:
There is no cure for Dyslexia. The covered overlays help tremendously, I 
can't explain how it works, but it just does. Of course you are going to 
find programs that do not work for some but work wonders for others. Two 
people will never have the same type of Dyslexia everyone's is different. 
I'm sorry, you said there is no test to see if someone has Dyslexia? How is 
that correct? I went to an educational psychologist who done a number of 
tests on myself and the results came back saying I was Dyslexic....But 
there is no testing?? How do you work that one out? If there is no actual 
test do people just make it up they are Dyslexic? I think not.....No matter 
what program you download whether that is for educational or recreation 
purposes they are going to be ones that are far too expensive than what is 
necessary. You just need to done some research before you go ahead and buy 
it.
comments.author: Nicole Campbell

comments.text:
Since there isn't a test to see if someone has dyslexia there is not really 
any way to say whether one approach would actually work better. When 
independent researchers have attempted to test various methods they've 
found that none worked better than another. When I talk about needing the 
same kinds of quality instruction I am referring to addressing the 
individual's need of support in phonics, phonemic awareness, and fluency 
support in addition to their vocabulary and comprehension instruction. I 
worry that the programs offered to families are often misleading and some 
charge outrageous fees for instruction that isn't really needed.
comments.author: Samuel DeJulio

comments.text:
There are people who swear that colored overlays helped "cure" them of 
dyslexia. It doesn't make it true. I think some of the claims made about 
these programs are the result of the power of suggestion, not the quality 
of the program.
comments.author: Samuel DeJulio

comments.text:
I completely and utterly disagree with you. I, myself am Dyslexic and have 
experienced how multi sensory intervention can improve Dyslexia first hand, 
it is not a cure but our minds do not work the same way other peoples do. 
We need a different learning technique and this is it! If you don't mind 
could you please explain what you mean by ' Students with Dyslexia need the 
same kind of quality reading instruction that students without Dyslexia 
need.
comments.author: Nicole Campbell

I am a dyslexic student. Biing dyslexic is realy hard.   You have to work 3 
times harder to get half of the grade of your class mates.  This doesnt 
mean you are stupid only because you can’t read the flavors of an ice cream 
or rite a poem doesnt mean you need to be teased.  I was diagnosed dislexic

confused every thing ( d b q p ).  It was hard fore me but now I am I 7th 
grade and I can read a book and write a good essay, but I had to work realy 
hard to practice. I was luky that in my school there is a learning support 
specialist, that who helped  me with. Being  dyslexic is hard but i really 
like it because you are different. you think in a different way.  So not a 
disease you will never stop having dislexia but you learn how to handle it 
 ﻿

comments.text:
+Vikram Khanzode You could have a mild form. I do, and my problems are 
nothing like the first paragraph. Usually I notice my dyslexia when reading 
text that is packed together. So I'll pull words from lines above and below 
what I'm reading and insert it into the sentence. I don't have trouble 
reading words regularly, but yes I have problems with words that are very 
similar.

For example: break and brake, sceptic and septic, tortuous and torturous, 
militate and mitigate, etc.


I don't replace letters of words with opposite letters, I'll just read a 
similar looking word instead of the correct one
comments.author: MercifiesProductions

top_comment.text:
I've always had math problems as a kid—and I still do, to the point where I 
completely avoid it. Multiplication and division, and subtraction and 
addition are what I still struggle with even even have trouble memorizing. 
Gosh, I didn't understand fractions until I was in grade 11 when it finally 
clicked. When I was young, I was a great speller but a mediocre reader. 
Right when I started college studying graphic design, my spelling/grammar, 
and even reading started to deteriorate. I would interchange letters and 
mispronounce words when speaking and sometimes not even realize it, I would 
misread/misinterpret written instructions, have trouble explaining things, 
and so forth. I don't even know what to do and I'm afraid my future career 
will suffer.﻿

comments.text:
If you think that's bad when i was about 7 or 8 years old i could barely 
add two numbers together, let alone try and multiply and divide. But the 
great thing about being Dyslexic is that the things you lack in usually 
make the other side of things enhanced way more then most people's brains. 
For example as I've already established I can't do maths or science at all 
because of the way my brain works, but my creative side of my brain is 
really good, and therefor makes me very good at making up stories and 
create detailed drawings. Obviously this doesn't apply to all Dyslexic 
people because as the person said in the video, everyone's Dyslexia tends 
to be very varied in terms of whether you find being creative hard or being 
analytic and mathematical hard.
comments.author: The Schofie

comments.text:

comments.text:
Aw man don't think of the cons to your dyslexia, think of your 
gifts.Dyslexics don't all develop the same gifts, but we do have certain 
mental functions in common. Here are the basic abilities all dyslexics 
share:
we can utilize the brain's ability to alter and create perceptions (the 
primary ability).
we are highly aware of the environment.
we are more curious than average.
we think mainly in pictures instead of words.
we are highly intuitive and insightful.
we think and perceive multi-dimensionally (using all the senses).
we can experience thought as reality.
we have vivid imaginations.

You can go so far with the special mind you have. All you need is 
confidence and overall patience
comments.author: Jalen Nieves

comments.text:

really bad when I'm tired because I'm less able to proof read my work.  In 
fact, I've already had to correct my spelled of "read" because I spelled it 
"reed".

You, for example, use the word "tell" instead of the contraction "'till" 
for "until".  Over the years, I've gotten much better at finding my mystakes 
mistakes because I keep making the same ones over and over again.
comments.author: Jason [Professor Fennec]

comments.text:
+Jason Fennec I have it and I have it bad.  I don't think I learned to read 
tell nearly the 6th grade and 9th grade tell I was only slightly bellow 
average.  I am now a college grad a Mechanical engineer.  Keep your head up 
focus on your strengths and stick too it.
comments.author: Craig Williams

comments.text:
Seems anything that is a deviation from the "norm" is a disorder of some 
kind or another now days.
comments.author: Zordrak Shadowfang

top_comment.text:
fucking hate having it, really annoying when your tying emails for jobs and 
college etc.... its so fucking annoying I need to read it through like 10 
times to make sure its right..... It took me an extra year to get better at 
English :/ ﻿
top_comment.author: Rémó

comments.text: +MrSHARKYY haha idk. its whatever though. gotta live no matter what

comments.text: my theory is I was dropped as a kid xD you?? haha

comments.text:
Yeah, on a lighter side of reading. Ive started to read for fun recently

of a book. Though Im not sure if Im dyslexic or not. Ive just always been

comments.author: Jordan B

top_comment.text:
In the 'Norm', people can't read in their dreams; their left hemisphere is 
used for reading and linguistics, whilst the right hemisphere uses are for 
dreams.
But for some neuro/psycho/prefix reason, I actually can read in my dreams 
perfectly.
Can someone explain this to me? I'm confused.﻿
top_comment.author: Adam Gonedridge

comments.text:
I used to read in my dreams in college.  I always read the texts, took 
extensive notes and read over them.  While my friends crammed all night and 
went into the exams exhausted, I always went to bed by at least midnight 
and spent the night studying in my sleep.  I have never been diagnosed as 
dyslexic, but my father and son both are.  Do you have any information on 
this being directly related to the way the dyslexic brain works?
comments.author: Lynn Heasley

comments.text:
+sitonmyfaceplzz the math  version of dylexia(lexi being letter) is 
dyscalculia(calcul means math).
comments.author: Adam Gonedridge

comments.text:
I am also learning Greek and Hungarian, but not French; I will do French 
later.
comments.author: Adam Gonedridge

comments.text:
Sometimes polyglots could face dyslexia in one language, I sometimes 
accidently read read as read. I may be dyslexic, while I'm learning German 
and French.
comments.author: Adam Gonedridge

comments.text:
Idk, I was diagnosed with an acute case of dyslexia a few years ago, but I 
am able to do math in my dreams so maybe you have dyslexia as well.
comments.author: sitonmyfaceplzz

top_comment.text:
Having lived with dyslexia I've come across a lot of videos and talks like 
this. This was one of the better ones. However, the whole 'all these other 
smart people had dyslexia' always, always, comes across as incredibly 
patronising. Maybe that's just me, but I have to grimace whenever it comes 
up.﻿
top_comment.author: Joel Cornah

comments.text:
I know what you mean. The purpose is to convey that dyslexia will not stop 
you from achieving greatness but it can come off as, "look some dyslexic 
people can be smart too."
comments.author: lostmyhead

comments.text:
+TheNotoriousKRP The fact that Einstein and many other high flyers was 
dyslexic proves conclusively that it is possible to be clever AND dyslexic 
- in other words it proves that being dyslexic is not the same as being 
thick.
comments.author: Edward Carron

comments.text:
It's probably because its easy for you to understand the, perhaps simple 
fact that just because Einstein was a genius and he had Dyslexia, doesn't 
necessarily mean or prove that everyone else with dyslexia will be a genius 
too, or even smart. Although, what's important isn't whether that is true 
or not, but rather the fact that people don't necessarily even know if it's 
true, but still they use it as a way to cheer you up as if you need 
cheering up because you are afflicted with some "terrible disability" that 
makes you "worse than them".
comments.author: TheNotoriousKRP

comments.text:
Just Google up Perceptual Learning in Action and you will see a specialist 
school which deals very successfully with dyslexics and is not patronising.
comments.author: Edward Carron

top_comment.text:
I am very fucking dyslexic. I am 23 and cant spell nothing. I hate it. I am 
also a slow learner. And sometimes have trouble getting my words out. I 
fill like my mind is trapped. I spent most of my life being the special one 
in class. And did not leave school with that many friends. So i ran away to 
Australia. And now been here for 3 years. No one understands how shit it 
is. I am interested in so may things. like quantum macanics. And space. But 
struggle to remember anything. I really wont to be sucssefull. And have my 
own caff one day. But dont even no if that will ever happen now. I would 
rather chop of my fucking arm than be stuck in side this metle cage. There 
is so much going on in my head but cant aritculate anything, READING THIS I 
ONLY USED SPELL CHECK ABOUT 50% OF THE TIME AND STILL CANT SPELL this is to 
give you an idear. ﻿
top_comment.author: Ben Robinson

comments.text: +Sandra Saenz You are fucking awsome. Thanks........
comments.author: Ben Robinson

comments.text:
+Ben Robinson A few years ago I got tired of the life I was living. I 
basically was partying, doing all kinds of drugs and hooking up with guys 
that didn't care about me. I didn't care if I lived or died at that point. 
It was January of 2011 and I almost over dosed on some ecstasy pills. I 
remember looking at myself in a mirror and asking God for help. I went to 
church that following Sunday and it felt so good to just be there. I 
listened to the surmen and it hit home so starting changing my life from 
that point on. I don't go to church anymore I think I just wanted to feel 
connected to god and now I know that our creater is within all of us at all 
times. I feel like everyone has to go through some shit so that you can 
realize who you truly are and that Is anything you want to be. You're only 
limited by your beliefs but it's taken me years to get where I am today. 
Reprogramming my mind with just positive thinking. Every day I repeat 
afermations that change all the years of shame, embarrassment and 
self-doubt. And Google has helped a lot too... lol the best advice I can 
give you is to find the things that make you feel a live and do them as 
much as you possibly can.
comments.author: Sandra Saenz

comments.text:
+Sandra Saenz Thanks for the insite maybe i should stop being a little 
bitch about it and just get on with it. Nothing is going to change it. Its 
just learning to cope with it. As you said eventurley you dont care about 
it so why should i now. Its just time wasting. I am finding now that there 
are some things i am good good at. But everything that i am good at like 
managemt and a good team leader i allways get hold back by simple paper 
work things that i just cant proses. I really have tried and its never 
going to happen. I need to figer a way to over come these probloms. What 
did you do? thanks for your incoraging reply. Cheers.
comments.author: Ben Robinson

comments.text:
Hi Ben yes I am I'm very blessed, I choose a career in social services 
witch I absolutely love. I get to help individuals every day and I go home 
knowing I made a difference in my community. But know one knows I'm dyslex 
and I'm at the point in my life where I don't care anymore so I plan on 
doing something about it. I want to help other people who are going through 
what I go through every day and teach them to build a better life for 
themselves. If you have any other questions please ask I'm here for you and 
anyone else. Much love to you!
comments.author: Sandra Saenz

comments.text:
+Sandra Saenz I gess its something you will never get over. Probs just got 
to learn to live with it. Can i ask you a question to you make a disent 
living.
comments.author: Ben Robinson

comments.text:
+Ben Robinson you are not alone. I think  many of us here can totally

top_comment.text:
Maybe dyslexic individuals could have an easier time using a language that 
more closely resembles the objects and concepts that the words represent, 
like a pictographic language. Has anyone done any experiments on this?﻿
top_comment.author: Alexander Abrams-Flohr

comments.text:
I think I have mild dyslexia. I learn Chinese went I was growing up, I had 
no problem with it. However, I was and still am terrible with Pinyin 
(phonetic pronunciation for Chinese).
I have problem with Vietnamese, which I consider my first language, and 
English.
So, yes, I think pictographic languages like Chinese maybe easier for 
dyslexic individuals to learn.
comments.author: Young Lam

comments.text:
I'm dyslexic and learning Chinese right now. The pictographic nature makes 
it easy but I still get stuck when it comes to the association of spoken 
words to pinyin. Was there anything specific you wanted to know about it?

comments.author: Aaron Landers

top_comment.text:
Found out from (public) school that our daughter is likely to be dyslexic. 
We're lucky that the school has class for dyslexics and that they have some 
general evaluation forms for teachers to detect it early.

Once we are aware of it, the behaviour and some of the learning 
difficulties of our daughter now makes sense. We've always been supportive 
of her about her learning difficulties before knowing, but now it makes it 
much easier to know how to support her better.﻿
top_comment.author: Khairil Yusof

comments.text:
http://www.virgin.com/richard-branson/a-new-typeface-for-dyslexics and yes, 
Richard Branson is a dyslexic.
comments.author: Lian Tze Lim

comments.text:
glad that as parents, you are open to the teacher's observations and 
recommendations.  hope she'd be able to blossom with courage and confidence 
to grow into an amazing person :)
comments.author: Emeelea Sani

comments.text:
I know of a dyslexic kid who is now a good dancer and into performing arts. 
8-)
comments.author: Joshua Ong

comments.text:
Most of our educators will not be able to differentiate it +Khairil Yusof 
hell...most parents and family might not even wanna acknowledge it and 
hence delay any possible early remedy
comments.author: Benedict Foo

comments.text:
+Asrulfeezam Haniffa thanks, yes she's lucky. In traditional educational, 
she would be seen as lazy or slow, so it's good that we found out early and 
we can help her learn in ways that suits her best.

The other point I learned is that it's good to get secondary opinions, 
because the symptoms at and early age are traits in common with most young 
kids such as short attention span and difficulties in learning to read. So 
even experienced educators may not be aware.
comments.author: Khairil Yusof

comments.text:
Its great if she is understood for her situation. My best wishes for your 
daughter and you +Khairil Yusof
comments.author: Asrulfeezam Haniffa

comments.text:

comments.text:
It depend on the language itself, like Japanese and Chinese, they are 
mainly pictograms, so you don't have to piece letters together like 
english, French, Spanish, ect so dyslexia doesn't really affect those 
learning Chinese or other languages using the pictogram system, I myself 
have dyslexia and afters going through intervention, the tables were turned 
and my Chinese dropped significantly while my english grades skyrocketed

comments.text:
don't know if what nicole says is true or not, (considering I know Spanish,

that it is in English, but I do suffer from it on both languages; Japanese, 
is far easier for me too.
I believe it might have to do with the alphabets (I believe they are far 
more straight-forward, in those, the only ones I have trouble (hiragana) 
are the 'chi' and 'sa' and very few kanji

have you tried the 'opendyslexic' font, I've found it helps me

top_comment.text:
(warning. im  NOT going to use spell check so you can see what the spelling 
one looks like. the hole point of this is to show you what it looks like 
when I don't have spell check) I have dyslexia. I was taken off the speshal 
education program when I was in 9th grade. My reading I a grade ubove my 
grade level but I still have a grate deal of difficity with my spelling. I 
am extreamly sensitive about it because I was bullied a lot in middle 
school. I cant text because I always feel scared that I might mess up and 
who im texting will point it out. having people critisize my spelling yes 
is understandable but I truly one of my gratest fears. I have come along 
way and this year in are state testing I scored partly profishiont in 
spelling and grammer but profishiont in reading. I still do have trouble 
with my spelling but I read all the time, because at one point it was 
something that I could no do. I am in are schools gt program for creativity 
(gt=gifted and talented) and I am considered smart among my peers. Sadly 
with spelling still being pore I have a hard time showing people that I am 
more then just some other speshal ed student.﻿
top_comment.author: Valerie Brand

comments.text: +Valerie Brand me 2
comments.author: adelle Pulga

comments.text:
I am a teacher, and schools honestly have no idea how to help students w/ 
dyslexia. You need someone to tutor you with an ORTON-GILLINGHAM program! 
Even Sylvan learning centers don't use a correct approach for dyslexia. If 
you see my comments above under another comment, you will see why you are 
so talented and gifted!!!!! Dyslexics have a larger right hemisphere than 
those w/out dyslexia! This is a fact. The right hemisphere is where you get 
Art, Athletics, Music, and so much more!!! You just learn differently, not 
wrong, not stupid! Some adult tutoring programs even use the 
Orton-Gillingham method!
comments.author: Kathy Sothman

+Chardonnay Aldin It was just a joke dude. Everyone makes grammar mistakes 
every now and then; I didn't mean to insult you personally, it was just

comments.author: Patrick McNerney

comments.text:
Fuck off I'm still good at thing I don't go to school I bet you do I hayt

comments.author: Chardonnay Aldin

comments.text:
+Chardonnay Aldin Why u gotta be such a dick dyslexia; you're the reason I 
had to go through private tutoring.
comments.author: Patrick McNerney

top_comment.text:
I'm wondering if I have dyslexia. Right now I'm working on my masters 
degree. Yes! masters degree, yet, I can't spell. I often feel embarrassed 
to go to the board and write anything. What I do, I try to write down the 
words that I have trouble with, many times, so I can remembered them. But, 
in a matter of a days or so.. I totally forget how to spell them again. I 
have struggle throughout my life, but I just notice how dumb I am, compared 
to others. If I was to compete in a spelling bee with 2nd graders, I will 
loose in the first round. And the bad thing is... that I will be a school 
teacher. Yes! an elementary school teacher. I really hope I can find a way 
to deal with this, as I really want to help kids and not hold them behind. 
However, I'm really creative, so I always find something that will deviate 
people from noticing how dumb I am, with my spelling. Another thing that I 
do in order to "sound smart" in front of  people, is that I write down 
fancy words.Yet, just like my formula to remember my spelling, I forget 
what those words mean, in a matter of days. Is this normal? Honestly, the 
only reason that I'm in school is because I dream a lot.But it's hard to 
keep up with people that really deserve to be in school.﻿
top_comment.author: Raul Aguilar

comments.text:
+Raul Aguilar
oh god I definitely relate! english is my second language as well, when 
people saw me having difficulties with reading Arabic, they thought I 
simply indulged myself too much in English that it affected my Arabic, but 
I have that problem with both Arabic AND English! and i have to say, not a 
lot of people where i live are educated about Dyslexia, and it's driving me 
insane!
comments.author: Reemoo4kill

comments.text:
One more thing. At first I though that it was because English is my second 
language. However, this happens with my Spanish to.
comments.author: Raul Aguilar

top_comment.text:
I had no idea I was dyslexic.  I was an avid reader.  Read a couple of books at a time. Had a bed book, a purse book, one for break-time on the job, even bathroom books.  But, I hated math.  I had no idea dyslexia could manifest through numbers.  I didn't find out I was dyslexic until I decided to face my math fears and got into finance.  Accounts payable/ receivable, payroll.  

I still did OK until, oddly enough, it came time for audits and I had to read numbers out loud.  I could look at numbers and record them accurately.  But not call them out loud accurately.  3, 6, and 9. I would  read those numbers out loud incorrectly, but write and add them correctly.   That  is how dyslexia manifests for me.  Be patient with you kids if they are having problems at school. It's not always their fault.
top_comment.author: makezmuzic

comments.text: +makezmuzic It's called dyscaculia, not dyslexia then.
comments.author: Jadu-演劇

comments.text:
i know the exact opposite of you i am not a avid reader but i do excel at 
maths, history and other subjects such as that. granted i am 14 and am 
mildly dyslexic so i do not really have the reading problem for say
comments.author: XxmentalshotgunXx

comments.text:
+the1andonlytitch I can relate to your struggles.  Although, my handwriting 
is atrocious, I will say learning to type was the best thing I ever 
learned.  I had wonderful teachers (now that I think back-I didn't think 
that then) who bought me special books and worked with me trying to improve 
my handwriting.  It never helped.

I can recall my first issues with dyslexia being in the early simple learn 
to read and write books when lower case b's, and d's and even the letter p 
gave me problems.  M's and N's were always bad.

Math gave me another problem all it's own.  Word problems were 
incomprehensible to me.

When I was in the fifth grade I had a special reading group that taught me 
to slowdown my reading.  This worked but it gave me another problem also. 
 Always to be the last to finish tests, sometimes not getting to finish, 
the frustration factor was to the point where I would pull out my hair. 
 Oral test were a nightmare.  Often, I couldn't  finish the answer in time 
for the next question.

Now I am an old man.  I had a good life.  I spent 23 years in the military, 
reached the rank of Warrant Officer, became a military court reporter, had 
a small unit I was assigned as commanding officer, I worked many  years at 
an ammunition plant, and have written six books.  So yes dyslexia gave me 
problems and it still does.
comments.author: J.R. Bowles

comments.text:
+J.R. Bowles It's strange there are two ways of learning to read I found 
this out in Psychology when I was writing a practice research report on 
dyslexia but they only teach the way you said where they teach through 
phonetics I think the education is fundamentally flawed they group people 
together by age (ignoring the fact that people develop at different rates) 
and they teach everyone in the same way (again ignoring individual 
differences) some people are set up to fail
comments.author: the1andonlytitch

comments.text:
I found out that I have dysgraphia 3 years ago when I decided to go back to 
college it's a bit different to dyslexia in the fact that it is pretty 
specific to hand writing but it is strange I have always felt that I was 
cognitive there with the rest of the kids in school yet I was never able to 
achieve good grades and was constantly being moved from the special needs 
group to the bottom group to the middle group then back to special needs 
again and eventually left school with poor grades never knowing that I was 
simply unable to write as well as most people but when I type on a computer 
my writing is really good but put a pen in my hand and I suddenly can't 
spell, leave out words, write unevenly and put capital letters where I 
shouldn't, my school let me down really because they probably had never 
heard of it and just assumed that I was dyslexic when I am not I hate to 
think what I could have achieved if I had the support I needed through 
school but fuck it I am in University and am doing fairly well so it's not 
all bad I doubt I would of found out what career I wanted to go into if it 
wasn't for the job I had for 3 years
comments.author: the1andonlytitch

comments.text:
+makezmuzic When I was a lad most teachers didn't have a clue about 
dyslexia.  I used to be come so frustrated that when I was alone I would 
punch myself in the face and bang my head against a wall.  I would sit in 
classrooms and pull my hair out in clumps.  The teachers tried to help but 
they didn't have a clue.  It was only later in life and my first military 
tour that I became educated enough to suspect it.  I had to have special 
reading classes throughout grade school.

I agree on the history if you don't remember it you're due to relive it.  I 
enjoy your posts also.  I did see an articles on the web today that has me 
smiling.  Stephen Hawkins had said that the God particle could cause the 
universe to collapse in onto itself. 
One of the books I wrote over 20 years ago I used that apocalyptic theme.

I still have trouble spelling.  Spell check is great, auto correct sort of 
sucks sometimes.  Especially when you reread it and can't see your mistake 
but then most people are like that to some extent.

As for the spelling, I am from the mountains of Virginia.  They taught us 
to spell phonetically the problem is they never taught us to enunciate 
correctly  lol
comments.author: J.R. Bowles

comments.text:
+J.R. Bowles HI J.R. I noticed that you gave this a "plus".  I wondered if 
you could relate, but I didn't want to be intrusive.  Thanks for saying 
something. With words it's vowels that get inverted. The same ones over and 
over again.  I think my teachers couldn't put it together because like you, 
I was an avid reader.  I've even had a teacher write on my homework for me 
to stop being rebellious and spell my words the correct way.  

By the way - Hats off to you for getting the word out on the idiocy of book 
banning.   In the past I spent a lot of money collecting antebellum 
memorabilia.  People would ask me why I collected that stuff.  It's part of 
our history.  I would take it into high schools along with negative images/ 
signs of American Indians, Asians, the Irish and Italian and lecture on how 
those images were used by the rich to divide the workers.  There is NOTHING 
in American history classes about unions.  And that is a crying shame. 
 Maybe some John Steinbeck, if they're lucky,  but thats it.
comments.author: makezmuzic

comments.text:
I've fought this all my life. Just today my mind said type a 4 on the 
keyboard, something jumped in and said 5. I typed 5 then my mind screamed 
no 4. The worst is inverting letters and inverting adjectives.
comments.author: J.R. Bowles

captions.text: Take a moment to read the following.

The brain is divided into two hemispheres.
The left hemisphere is generally in charge of language
while the right typically handles spatial activities.
that the brains of those with dyslexia

This means, when they read a word,

and suggests that to better understand the perspectives
